awd_titl_txt: I/UCRC Phase II:  ASU Research Site of the NSF Net-Centric and Cloud Software and Systems I/UCRC
awd_abstract_narration:
With this award, the Arizona State University IUCRC site of the Net-centric and Cloud Software and Systems (NCSS) I/UCRC will transition to a Phase 2 Site. The NCSS involves University of North Texas (Lead Site), Southern Methodist University, University of Texas at Dallas, Missouri University of S&T and Arizona State University. The site has already established the necessary intellectual base and marketing infrastructure to attract and retain industry partners for Phase 2, and has an excellent track record of industry membership and engagement within the NCSS. Networked sensing systems are important in homeland security, Net Centric defense systems, industry applications, health monitoring and other areas. The Phase 2 center will enable the creation of new capabilities in sensor signal processing and will bridge the gap between sensor development and large scale sensor deployment. The center is uniquely positioned to promote fundamental research, education, scholarship, and industry activities in an innovative manner that will continue integrating well in the existing Net-Centric umbrella. 

With the NCSS, this Site focuses on research areas such as digital signal and image processing, sensor networks, information technologies and algorithm and cloud software development for wireless communications.  Specific areas of planned research advances and contributions include:  a) Advances in radar direction of arrival estimation using virtual sensor arrays, b) development of networked sensor monitoring algorithms and cloud software which predict process failures, c) fault detection in sensors monitoring networked PV arrays, d) networked imaging sensors for activity detection, and e) net centric approaches with camera arrays for image understanding.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

por.por_cntn:
The ASU Industry University Cooperative Research Center (I/UCRC) Phase 2 site of the Net Centric Cloud and Computing Systems (NCSS) works closely with industry partners in the areas of signal processing, machine learning, sensor networks and communications systems.  The I/UCRC site is strongly connected with our Sensor Signal and Information Processing (SenSIP) Center at Arizona State University (ASU) which is directed by the PI.  SenSIP provides personnel and facilities for ASU faculty, industry (I/UCRC) partners and student researchers working in signal processing and machine learning (ML) for sensor related applications. Specific research problems that our I/UCRC site worked on include: information extraction, wireless transmission, signal processing, machine learning, and interpretation of signals acquired from integrated sensing systems. Such sensing systems are important in the defense, sustainability and healthcare areas and in a variety of important industry applications requiring AI-based research and analytics.  During the Phase 2 of this I/UCRC program, the ASU NCSS site signed I/UCRC membership agreements with several companies including: Alphacore,  CI Labs, Intel, Lightsense, NXP, ON Semi, Prime Solutions Group, Poundra, Qualcomm, Raytheon, Resonea, Samsung, and Sprint (now T-Mobile).  In Phase 2 (2016-2022), the ASU I/UCRC SenSIP site trained more than fifty PhD and Masters students several of whom are working in high-tech companies. The center also hosted an NSF SenSIP REU site that trained a diverse group of more than forty students.  Four former students of the PI have started their own companies and three others have been hired as tenure-track faculty. The center has also established internships with industry partners.

Capabilities and facilities established during the I/UCRC Phase 2 award enabled us to establish  several other NSF projects including: CPS, RAPID, IUSE, IRES, MRI, RET and REU. In addition, sponsored international collaborations have been formed with Dublin City University, Imperial College, Tec de Monterrey, and University of Cyprus. All international collaborations had outcomes in terms of research, publications and student internships/visits.  

Faculty affiliated with this ASU site, have developed intellectual property in digital signal processing machine learning, imaging, solar energy monitoring and sensor systems. In all, more than twenty US patents were established and several pre-disclosures were filed by the PI and his colleagues. Center projects have been established in several research areas that involve signal processing, machine learning, PV monitoring, quantum computing and sensor systems. Collaborative research in these areas resulted in establishing publications and book monographs. Recent work in quantum machine learning brought in research sponsorship from General Dynamics and NSF.  Additional sponsored work in software defined imaging and calibration of accelerometers was also part of our Phase 2 activities. Sustainability endeavors of the center include a project on embedding sensors and machine learning algorithms in utility-scale photovoltaic arrays (efforts supported by NSF GOALI and Poundra LLC). In all, more than twenty five annual core research projects have been established by the center during Phase 1 and Phase 2 at the ASU I/UCRC site.

Important facilities established include a dedicated LTE picocell, an 18kW solar monitoring facility at the ASU MTW, privileged access to the ASU IBM quantum hub, and several GPU-enabled computing facilities for deep learning research.  The Phase 2 site continued its outreach to several high schools and community colleges and an NSF RET project for teachers was established.  Research activities with industry and research sponsors will continue after phase 2 and updates and new results will be posted at http://sensip.asu.edu.

 


Last Modified: 05/29/2023
Modified by: Andreas S Spanias
